ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Gained early skills in reading, writing and speaking in Arabic. Lots of vocabulary development and practical conversation practice.
I learned how to read the arabic script at a basic level, and how to engage in basic conversation and listenting.
We learned the Arabic alphabet, phrases, vocabulary, and basic grammar.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the grading strucutre is too skewed for the beginning of the year. Exams that counted for 40% of the grade were done in October/Nov. There was no final to demonstrate my growth during the semester. I do like the teaching format, and the textbooks were helpful.

I believe this course could do for a lot of restructuring.  Important materials and vocab were often mentioned once and then not reviewed again.  Additionally, we were often not told of presentation details or other important information until the Sunday before class, leaving many people a bit stranded over the weekend and then stuck to cram in work Sunday evening.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Highly recommend for students looking to start their language requirement.
It is the most challenging class I have taken, but for the most part I enjoyed it. The pace is difficult , especially in the beginning of the year.

If you want to learn Arabic, this is a good way to start, but beware, you must do most of the work yourself.  I came in expecting what we learned in class to be close to enough to learn the material, but in reality, you will probably need to spend at least double the time you spend in class working on the material outside of the class as class time is more an introduction to the material and you are expected to do a good bit of the heavy lifting in learning the material outside of class.
